description: Check if you're old enough, or have the right kind of driving licence, to drive different kinds of vehicle

details.body: Check if you’re old enough, or have the right kind of driving licence, to drive different kinds of vehicle.

nodes.body: Choose the kind of vehicle you want to drive from the list. If you know the vehicle category these are also shown.

options.label: Other specialist vehicles (categories G, H and K)

nodes.body:
You can apply for a provisional licence at 15 years and 9 months old. You can learn to drive a car and take a test at 17.

If you already have a provisional licence to ride a moped, you do not need to reapply.

If you have a disability or long-term health condition

In England and Wales

You can learn to drive a car and take a test when you’re 16 if you get either:

  • the ‘mobility part’ of Personal Independence Payment (PIP) at the higher rate
  • the ‘mobility component’ at the higher rate of Disability Living Allowance (DLA) for children and have applied for PIP - you must be receiving DLA before you turn 16 to be eligible

In Scotland

You can learn to drive a car and take a test when you’re 16 if you get any of the following:

  • the ‘mobility component’ of Child Disability Payment (CDP) at the higher rate - you must be receiving CDP before you turn 16 to be eligible
  • the ‘mobility component’ at the higher rate of DLA for children and are waiting to be transferred to get CDP
  • the ‘mobility part’ of Adult Disability Payment (ADP) at the enhanced rate
  • the ‘mobility part’ of PIP at the higher rate and are waiting to be transferred to get ADP
nodes.title: You’re not old enough to learn to drive a car yet

nodes.body:
You can apply for a provisional licence. You can learn to drive a car and take a test at 17.

If you already have a provisional licence to ride a moped, you do not need to reapply.

If you have a disability or long-term health condition

In England and Wales

You can learn to drive a car and take a test when you’re 16 if you get any of the following:

  • the ‘mobility part’ of Personal Independence Payment (PIP) at the higher rate
  • the ‘mobility component’ at the higher rate of Disability Living Allowance (DLA) for children and have applied for PIP - you must be receiving DLA before you turn 16 to be eligible

In Scotland

  • the ‘mobility component’ of Child Disability Payment (CDP) at the higher rate - you must be receiving CDP before you turn 16 to be eligible
  • the ‘mobility component’ at the higher rate of DLA for children and are waiting to be transferred to get CDP
  • the ‘mobility part’ of Adult Disability Payment (ADP) at the enhanced rate
  • the ‘mobility part’ of PIP at the higher rate and are waiting to be transferred to get ADP
nodes.title: You normally need to be 17 to learn to drive a car

nodes.body:
Apply for a provisional licence. If you already have a provisional licence to ride a moped, you do not need to reapply.

You must obey the rules for learning to drive a car.

If you take your driving test in an automatic car you can only drive automatic cars.
nodes.title: You can apply for a provisional licence and learn to drive a car

nodes.body: You can apply for a provisional licence to ride a moped when you’re 16.
nodes.title: You cannot start learning to ride a motorbike until you’re 17

nodes.body:
You’ll then need to compete compulsory basic training (CBT) and take the A1 theory and practical tests within 2 years to get a full A1 licence.

Category A1 covers motorbikes not exceeding:

  • 125cc engine size
  • 11kW power output
  • 0.1kW/kg power to weight ratio

Existing licence holders

You can ride the category of motorbike you’ve got on your licence.

If you want to ride larger motorbikes you need to follow the rules below.

The rules for motorbike driving licences changed in January 2013, but it does not matter when you got your licence - if you want to ride a larger motorbike, the new rules will still apply to you.

Riding larger motorbikes

If you want to ride larger bikes you’ve got 2 options.

Direct access

You can wait until you’re old enough to ride the kind of bike you want, then take the theory and practical tests for that type of bike. You need to be 19 to ride medium-sized motorbikes (category A2). You need to be 24 to take the large motorbike direct access test.

Progressive access

First get a full licence for a category A1 small motorbike.

Once you’ve had 2 years’ experience on this licence you can take the practical test for an A2 medium-sized motorbike.

Once you’ve had a full A2 licence for 2 years you can take the practical test for category A large motorbikes.

Motorbike categories

Category A1 small motorbikes

These are motorbikes not exceeding:

  • 125cc engine size
  • 11kW power output
  • 0.1kW/kg power to weight ratio

Category A2 medium-sized motorbikes

These are motorbikes, with or without a sidecar not exceeding:

  • 35kW power output
  • 0.2kW/kg power to weight ratio

They also cannot be derived from a vehicle of more than double its power.

Category A large motorbikes

These are bikes unlimited in size and power, with or without a sidecar.
nodes.title: You can apply for a provisional licence for a small motorbike (category A1)

nodes.body:
You’ll then need to compete compulsory basic training (CBT) and take the theory and practical tests for the kind of motorbike you want to ride within 2 years.

Existing licence holders

If you’ve already got a motorbike licence you can ride the category of motorbike you’ve got on your licence.

If you want to ride larger motorbikes you need to follow the rules below.

Riding larger motorbikes

If you want to ride larger bikes (category A) you’ve got 2 options.

Direct access

You can wait until you’re 24 then take the theory and practical tests for that type of bike.

Progressive access

First get a full licence for a category A2 medium-sized motorbike.

Once you’ve had 2 years’ experience on this licence you can take the practical test for a category A large motorbike.

Motorbike categories

Category A1 small motorbikes

These are motorbikes not exceeding: - 125cc engine size - 11kW power output - 0.1kW/kg power to weight ratio

Category A2 medium-sized motorbikes

These are motorbikes, with or without a sidecar not exceeding:

  • 35kW power output
  • 0.2kW/kg power to weight ratio

Category A2 motorbikes cannot be derived from a vehicle of more than double its power.

Category A large motorbikes

These are bikes unlimited in size and power, with or without a sidecar.
nodes.title: You can apply for a provisional licence for either a category A1 small motorbike or a category A2 medium-sized motorbike

nodes.body:
You’ll then need to complete compulsory basic training (CBT) and take the theory and practical tests for the kind of motorbike you want to ride within 2 years.

You’ll need to pass the practical test on a bike with a power output of at least 50kW and a minimum kerb weight of 180kg to ride any size of bike.

Motorbike categories

Category A1 small motorbikes

These are motorbikes not exceeding:

  • 125cc engine size
  • 11kW power output
  • 0.1kW/kg power to weight ratio

Category A2 medium-sized motorbikes

These are motorbikes, with or without a sidecar not exceeding:

  • 35kW power output
  • 0.2kW/kg power to weight ratio

They also cannot be derived from a vehicle of more than double its power.

Category A large motorbikes

These are bikes unlimited in size and power, with or without a sidecar. You can ride the category of motorbike you took your test on.
nodes.title: You can apply for a provisional licence then learn to ride any size of motorbike

nodes.body:
This is shown as category P on your licence.

You will not need to take compulsory basic training (CBT) or a full practical test.

Mopeds have a maximum speed of 31mph and an engine size of up to 50cc.
nodes.title: You can already ride a moped up to a maximum speed of 50km/h

nodes.body:
This covers mopeds with a maximum speed of 50km/h.

You’ll need to take compulsory basic training (CBT). You can then ride mopeds for as long as your car driving licence is valid.
nodes.title: You’ll already have category P moped entitlement on your licence

nodes.body:
You can apply for a provisional licence at 15 years and 9 months old. You can learn to ride a moped and take a moped test at 16.

You must take:

  • compulsory basic training before you ride on the road
  • the moped test within 2 years

The same licence covers you to learn to drive a car at 17. You do not need to reapply.
nodes.title: You cannot learn to ride a moped until you’re 16

nodes.body:
You can apply for a provisional licence. You can learn to ride a moped and take a moped test.

You must take:

  • compulsory basic training before you ride on the road
  • the moped test within 2 years

The same licence covers you to learn to drive a car at 17. You do not need to reapply.

Category AM mopeds have a maximum speed between 25km/h and 45km/h.

Category Q mopeds are 2 or 3-wheeled mopeds with a maximum speed of 25km/h.
nodes.title: You can apply for a provisional licence and learn to ride a moped

nodes.body:
Check if you have a category D1 entitlement online.

Towing

You may also have the C1+E towing entitlement, which means you can drive C1 vehicles with a trailer up to a combined weight of 8,250kg.

The fully loaded trailer cannot weigh more than the unladen (empty) weight of the vehicle, however.
nodes.title: You may be able to drive medium sized vehicles

nodes.body: Once you’re 18 you can apply for a provisional medium-sized vehicle entitlement (category C1) and take the C1 test.
nodes.title: You cannot drive a medium-sized vehicle until you’re 18

nodes.body:
You’ll then need to take the C1 test.

Towing

If you’re 21 or over and have your C1 entitlement you can then apply for a provisional C1+E towing entitlement then take the C1+E test.
nodes.title: You can apply for a provisional medium-sized vehicle entitlement

nodes.body: You’ll then have to pass the medium-sized vehicle (category C1) test.
nodes.title: You need to have a full car licence and be at least 18 before applying for a provisional entitlement to drive medium-sized vehicles
You cannot drive large vehicles and lorries

nodes.body:
You can drive large vehicles professionally if both of the following apply:

  • you’re between 18 and 20
  • you take a CPC qualification

You’ll also need:

  • a full car licence
  • to apply for provisional category C entitlement
  • to take the category C test
nodes.title: You can drive large vehicles if you have a CPC qualification

nodes.body:
You’ll then need to take a category C test.

Towing

Once you’ve passed your test you can apply for a provisional towing entitlement (category C+E).
nodes.title: You can apply for provisional large vehicle and lorry entitlement (category C)

nodes.body:
You’ll then need to apply for provisional large vehicle and lorry provisional entitlement (category C) and take the category C test.

Towing

Once you’ve passed your category C test you can then apply for a provisional towing entitlement (category C+E) then take the towing test.
nodes.title: You’ll need to first get your full car driving licence

nodes.body: You’ll then have to pass the minibus (category D1 test).
nodes.title: You need to have a full car licence to apply for a provisional entitlement to drive a minibus

nodes.body:
You can drive a minibus with your car licence (category B) if both of the following apply:

  • the vehicle has no more than 16 passenger seats
  • you’re not towing a trailer

Being paid to drive (driving for ‘hire or reward’)

You usually cannot drive a minibus for ‘hire or reward’ (for example, as part of your job) if you have code 101 on your driving licence. You might be able to drive for hire or reward for an organisation like a school or local authority if you meet certain conditions.

You might be able to get a permit if all of the following apply:

  • you’re driving for a non-profit organisation (such as a charity or school)
  • you need to charge passengers to cover the costs of driving the minibus
  • you’re not making a profit

Read the guide on permits for more information.

You might be able to drive a minibus abroad. Contact the driving licence authority in the country you’re visiting.

Add category D1 to your licence

Fill in a D2 application form if you do not meet the conditions and want to drive a minibus.

You must also ask a doctor to fill in a D4 medical report.
nodes.title: You may be able to drive a minibus with your car licence (category B)

nodes.body:
Check if you have a D1 entitlement on your licence online.

You may still be able to drive a minibus with your car licence (category B) as long as all the following apply:

  • you’re 21 or older
  • you’ve had your driving licence for at least 2 years
  • the maximum weight of the minibus is 3,500kg (or 4,250kg including specialist equipment for disabled passengers, such as a wheelchair ramp)
  • you’re not towing a trailer
  • the minibus is used by a non-commercial body for social purposes
  • you do not get paid except for expenses, for example fuel and parking costs
  • you provide the service on a voluntary basis

Being paid to drive (driving for ‘hire or reward’)

You usually cannot drive a minibus for ‘hire or reward’ (for example, as part of your job) unless you’re driving for an organisation like a local authority and you meet certain conditions.

You might be able to get a permit if all of the following apply:

  • you’re driving for a non-profit organisation (such as a charity or school)
  • you need to charge passengers to cover the costs of driving the minibus
  • you’re not making a profit

Read the guide on permits for more information.

You might also be able to drive a minibus abroad. Contact the driving licence authority in the country you’re visiting.

Driving a minibus professionally

You must take a D1 minibus test if you want to drive minibuses professionally. Apply for a provisional D1 licence by filling in a D2 application form.

You must also ask a doctor to fill in a D4 medical report.
nodes.title: You can drive a minibus if you have category D1 entitlement on your licence

nodes.body:
You can drive a minibus in the UK with your car licence (category B) if all of the following apply:

  • you’re 21 or older
  • you’re not using the minibus ‘for hire or reward’ (you may see ‘code 101’ written on your licence)
  • you’ve had your driving licence for 2 years or more
  • the minibus is 3.5 tonnes or less (or 4.25 tonnes including specialist equipment for disabled passengers, such as a wheelchair ramp)
  • you’re not towing a trailer

Add category D1 to your licence

Fill in a D2 application form if you do not meet the conditions and you want to drive a minibus.

You must also ask a doctor to fill in a D4 medical report.
nodes.title: You may be able drive a minibus in the UK with your car licence (category B)

nodes.body:
Check if you have a category D entitlement online.

Otherwise, you’ll normally have to wait until you’re 24 to drive one.

Driving a bus at 17

You can only drive a bus when you’re 17 if you’re a member of the armed forces.

Driving a bus at 18

You can drive a bus when you’re 18 if you’re learning to either:

  • take your Passenger Carrying Vehicle (PCV) driving test
  • get your Driver Certificate of Professional Competence (CPC)

You can only drive this type of vehicle if any of the following also apply:

  • you’re not carrying any passengers
  • you are carrying passengers, but driving on a regular route that’s less than 31 miles
  • you do not drive the vehicle abroad

If you’ve passed your PCV driving test

You can drive a category D1 vehicle (such as a minibus) if you’ve passed your PCV driving test and have one of the following:

  • a Driver CPC
  • a bus operator’s licence
  • a minibus permit
  • a community bus permit

Driving a bus at 20

You can drive a bus in the UK when you’re 20 if you’ve passed your PCV driving test and got your Driver CPC. You cannot drive a bus abroad.

Driving a bus at 21

You can drive a bus in the UK or abroad when you’re 21 if you’ve passed your PCV driving test and got your Driver CPC.

You can also drive a bus in the UK when you’re 21 if the bus is either:

  • being used by the fire service or by the police to maintain public order
  • being road tested after it’s been repaired or serviced
nodes.title: You might be able to drive a bus if you have a category D entitlement on your licence

nodes.body: You’ll need to apply for provisional bus entitlement (category D) then take a category D test.
nodes.title: You can learn to drive a bus

nodes.body: You must also normally be 24 or over.
nodes.title: You’ll need a full car driving licence before you can apply for provisional bus entitlement (category D) and take a category D test

nodes.body: You can view your driving licence entitlement online.
nodes.title: You can drive a tractor and do not need to take a test

nodes.body:
Once you’re 16 you can apply for provisional tractor entitlement (category F) then take a tractor test.

You’ll then be able to drive smaller tractors less than 2.45m wide and tow trailers less than 2.45m wide with 2 wheels or 4 close-coupled wheels.

Alternatively you can wait until you’re 17 then take a tractor test to drive any size of tractor.

If you get a full car licence you can drive a tractor without having to take a special tractor test.
nodes.title: You cannot drive a tractor until you’re 16

nodes.body:
You’ll then be able to drive smaller tractors less than 2.45m wide and tow trailers less than 2.45m wide with 2 wheels or 4 close-coupled wheels.

Alternatively you can wait until you’re 17 then take a tractor test to drive any size of tractor.

If you get a full car licence you can drive a tractor without having to take a special tractor test.
nodes.title: You can apply for a provisional tractor entitlement (category F) then take a test

nodes.body:
You’ll then have to take a test to drive any type of tractor.

If you get a full car licence you can drive a tractor without having to take a special tractor test.
nodes.title: You can apply for a provisional tractor entitlement (category F)

nodes.body:
You’ll also have provisional entitlement to drive some road rollers and tracked vehicles.

Road rollers (category G)

You already have provisional entitlement to drive non-steam road rollers up to 11,690kg and not made for carrying loads. You’ll have to take a category G test to get full entitlement for these vehicles.

Tracked vehicles (category H)

You already have provisional entitlement to drive tracked vehicles up to 3,500kg. You’ll have to take a category H test to get full entitlement for these vehicles.
nodes.title: You can already drive mowing machines or pedestrian-controlled vehicles (category K) without taking a special test

nodes.body: You’ll also have provisional entitlement to drive all kinds of road rollers and tracked vehicles. You’ll need to take tests in these vehicles to get full entitlement for them.
nodes.title: You can already drive mowing machines or pedestrian-controlled vehicles (category K) without taking a special test
You cannot drive category G, H or K vehicles

nodes.body: You’ll need to apply for a provisional category K licence then take a test.
nodes.title: You can drive mowing machines or pedestrian-controlled vehicles (category K)

nodes.body:
You’ll then need to take the right type of test.

Road rollers (category G)

You can apply for entitlement to drive small non-steam powered road rollers up to 11,690kg. They must have metal or hard rollers and not be made for carrying loads.

If you get a full car licence you automatically get provisional entitlement to drive these kinds of road rollers.

Tracked vehicles (category H)

You can apply for provisional entitlement to drive tracked vehicles up to 3,500kg.

If you get a full car licence you automatically get provisional entitlement to drive these kinds of road rollers.
nodes.title: You can apply for a provisional licence to drive mowing machines or pedestrian-controlled vehicles (category K) and some road rollers (category G) and tracked vehicles (category H)

nodes.body: If you get a full car licence you can drive category K vehicles without a special test and automatically get provisional entitlement to drive all kinds of road rollers and tracked vehicles.
nodes.title: You can apply for provisional entitlement then take the right test to drive mowing machines or pedestrian-controlled vehicles (category K) and all types of road rollers and tracked vehicles

nodes.body:
You must take compulsory basic training (CBT) before you ride a light quad bike.

You must take a moped test within 2 years.
nodes.title: You can ride a light quad bike after you've done compulsory basic training

nodes.body:
You can apply for a provisional licence at 15 years and 9 months old. You can learn to ride a light quad bike and take a moped test at 16.

You must take:

  • compulsory basic training before you ride on the road
  • the moped test within 2 years

The same licence covers you to learn to drive a car at 17. You do not need to reapply.

If you have a physical disability

You can learn to ride or take a test on a quad bike if you have a physical disability. You may also be eligible for Personal Independence Payment (PIP).
nodes.title: You cannot learn to ride a light quad bike until you’re 16

nodes.body:
You can apply for a provisional licence. You can learn to ride a light quad bike and take a moped test. You must take:

  • compulsory basic training before you ride on the road
  • the moped test within 2 years

The same licence covers you to learn to drive a car at 17. You do not need to reapply.

If you have a physical disability

You can learn to ride or take a test on a light quad bike if you have a physical disability. You may also be eligible for Personal Independence Payment (PIP).
nodes.title: You can apply for a provisional licence and learn to ride a light quad bike
You can already drive motor tricycles and do not need to take a special test

nodes.body: Go back to the start of this tool and choose the motorbike option to see how to get these licence entitlements.
nodes.title: You’ll need a category A1 motorbike licence to ride motor tricycles up to power output 15kW, and a category A motorbike licence to ride trikes with a power output more than 15kW

nodes.body: You’ll then have to pass the minibus (category D1) test.
nodes.title: You need to have a full car licence to apply for a provisional entitlement to drive a minibus
You can ride a heavy quad bike

nodes.body:
You can start learning and take the test at 17. You’ll need to apply for a provisional licence first.

If you already have a provisional licence to ride a moped and drive a car, you do not need to reapply.

If you have a disability or long-term health condition

You can learn to ride or take a test on a quad bike if you have a physical disability.

In England and Wales

You can start learning and take the test at 16 if you get either:

  • the ‘mobility part’ of Personal Independence Payment (PIP) at the higher rate
  • the ‘mobility component’ at the higher rate of Disability Living Allowance (DLA) for children and have applied for PIP - you must be receiving DLA before you turn 16 to be eligible

In Scotland

You can start learning and take the test at 16 if you get any of the following:

  • the ‘mobility component’ of Child Disability Payment (CDP) at the higher rate - you must be receiving CDP before you turn 16 to be eligible
  • the ‘mobility component’ at the higher rate of DLA for children and are waiting to be transferred to get CDP
  • the ‘mobility part’ of Adult Disability Payment (ADP) at the enhanced rate
  • the ‘mobility part’ of PIP at the higher rate and are waiting to be transferred to get ADP
nodes.title: You need a full driving licence (category B) to ride a heavy quad bike

nodes.body:
You can start learning and take the test at 17.

You can apply for a provisional licence when you’re 15 years and 9 months old.

If you already have a provisional licence to ride a moped and drive a car, you do not need to reapply.

If you have a disability or long-term health condition

You can learn to ride or take a test on a quad bike if you have a physical disability.

In England and Wales

You can start learning and take the test at 16 if you get either:

  • the ‘mobility part’ of Personal Independence Payment (PIP) at the higher rate
  • the ‘mobility component’ at the higher rate of Disability Living Allowance (DLA) for children and have applied for PIP - you must be receiving DLA before you turn 16 to be eligible

In Scotland

You can start learning and take the test at 16 if you get any of the following:

  • the ‘mobility component’ of Child Disability Payment (CDP) at the higher rate - you must be receiving CDP before you turn 16 to be eligible
  • the ‘mobility component’ at the higher rate of DLA for children and are waiting to be transferred to get CDP
  • the ‘mobility part’ of Adult Disability Payment (ADP) at the enhanced rate
  • the ‘mobility part’ of PIP at the higher rate and are waiting to be transferred to get ADP
nodes.title: You need a full driving licence (category B) to ride a heavy quad bike

nodes.body:
You need to have your full car driving licence (category B) before you can drive a heavy quad bike.

You’ll need to apply for a provisional licence and then pass a driving test.

If you have a physical disability

You can learn to ride or take a test on a quad bike if you have a physical disability.
nodes.title: You cannot ride a heavy quad bike until you have your full car driving licence

nodes.body:
You must keep to the rules for learning to drive a car.

If you have a physical disability

You can learn to ride or take a test on a quad bike if you have a physical disability.
nodes.title: You cannot ride a heavy quad bike until you have your full car driving licence

nodes.body:
You’ll need to take:

  • compulsory basic training before you ride on the road
  • a moped test within 2 years

You will not need to take compulsory basic training if your licence was issued before 1 February 2001.

If you have a physical disability

You can learn to ride or take a test on a quad bike if you have a physical disability.
nodes.title: You can ride a light quad bike if you take compulsory basic training and pass a moped test
You can ride a light quad bike

nodes.body:
You’ll need to complete compulsory basic training (CBT) before you ride on the road.

You will not need to take compulsory basic training if your licence was issued before 1 February 2001.
nodes.title: You can ride a light quad bike if you take compulsory basic training
